meanings.definition: To make someone feel disgusted or nauseated.
meanings.sent1: The smell of rotten food can sicken people.
meanings.sent2: The spoiled milk started to sicken me.
meanings.sent3: The sight of the slimy creature made him sicken and run away.
meanings.sent4: The gruesome scene in the movie sicken her to the core.
meanings.sent5: The taste of the expired meat sicken her stomach instantly.

meanings.sent1: Eating too much candy can sicken your stomach.
meanings.sent2: He began to sicken with a fever after playing in the rain.
meanings.sent3: The idea of going to school on a Saturday made him sicken.
meanings.sent4: The news of the accident sicken her heart with worry.
meanings.sent5: The polluted water made the fish sicken and die off.

meanings.definition: To cause someone to lose interest or enthusiasm.
meanings.sent1: The repetitive tasks started to sicken him of his job.
meanings.sent2: The constant rain began to sicken her desire to go outside.
meanings.sent3: The long lecture on a Friday afternoon sicken the students.
meanings.sent4: The lack of progress sicken her motivation to continue.
meanings.sent5: The never-ending meetings sicken the employees with boredom.
